Steps to Set Up Localization

Architecture Notes

  • Crafter has no native concept of translation
    • That doesn't mean that it cannot be built employed using standard design patterns
  • What is translation support?
    • Content must know its language
    • Content must be able to identify its translations
  • This is ultimately done by linking the translations to the source
    • sometimes by designating a language as the source and translations link to the id of the source
    • sometimes by introducing a whole new identifier that is common to both
  • This approach:
    • Place content in a folder corresponding to its locale
    • Linkage between translations is specified by the path - two files in the same location but with different language folders are translations of one another.
      • e.g.
        • These two are translations: 
          • /site/website/en/home/index.xml
          • /site/website/en/home/index.xml
        • So are these:
          • /site/website/en/style/hats/index.xml
          • /site/website/es/style/hats/index.xml
        • But these are not:
          • /site/website/en/style/hats/index.xml
          • /site/website/es/style/argentinian-hats/index.xml
  • How can this be used?
    • Two primary use cases
      • Content creation
        • I want to create a translation of item A which is in English, into Spanish
      • Content lookup
        • I want to render an item with a particular path in specific language
    • Only using a 2-letter locale code. We could have used the whole locale code instead.
    • Notes about the current implementation:
    • We could take this approach, but we did not
    • This approach relies on the location of content in the content source tree
      • The system will look up a translation in the same location as the source, but with a different prefix corresponding to the language
        • Current implementation just uses a 2-letter locale code, but you can use full locale codes too.
      • So what do you do when the item requested is not present in the desired locale?
        • Crafter falls back to a designated language for the site
          • e.g. if /jp/style is not present, it will return /en/style
